data.title: Unattractive Structure Filled With Bureaucrats and the Welfare Class
data.text: Ok, if I have someone visiting Houston, one of the last places I'm ever going to take them is city hall.  The building itself looks like it was designed by a Soviet architectural bureau. But, wait, there's more.  Right next door is a park where it is politically correct to let all kinds of vagrants hang out and believe me, you do not want to be anywhere near here after dark.  It gets better.  Often, you will find every welfare and government-sponsored group you can think of having either a protest or a festival on the grounds.  Sometimes, you can even be treated to a class-warfare spiel by our mayor.  Why anyone would come here is beyond me.

data.title: Lovely building in a park
data.text:
Go inside and have a look, it is worth it.
The security people are very helpful and told us about the free green bus that does the loop around the city.

data.title: Renovation complete
data.text: The renovation of the first floor was completed in December 2015.  I have been to several functions in the first floor foyer and it is contemporary and spacious.  Out in front of City Hall is a two tier terrace with a wide brick paver esplanade surrounding a reflection pool.  The site hosts multiple events and is a relaxing place for lunch and work breaks.  Highly recommend to recharge energy from a hectic work schedule.

data.title: This is it! Corruption & Moron central for Houston...
data.text:
SO if you wantot catch a corrup politician, or catch a glimpse of a over paid city official, WOW, yo hvae come to the right town. If you act quick you might see Mayor Porker, the Queen of Special Interest politics, A rare site, if you catch her. Maybe you can even see her with the special interests paying her off.
In the Texas political dictonary, if you look up the word "hypocrite", you can see her picture.

data.title: Historical and dated
data.text: This seems like the same place I visited as a child with some upgrades which unfortunate seem to have actually diminished the significance of the building as hot seat of power for Houston.

data.title: Houston City Hall
data.text: It is pretty cool because of the reflection pool in the front.  It is really old and an icon of the city.  Not much else.

data.title: Historical building and good visitor's center
data.text: A unique architectural building built in the '30s make the outside interesting to look at. There are a couple of other buildings nearby on the south side from about the same time period. The visitors center on the first floor also make this a reasonable visit. The visitors center is quite large and filled with information for the area (not just Houston). You can even buy souvenirs there. The desk is staffed to help you find what else to do in Houston.

data.title: The Glory of a mighty Houston
data.text: Just a short walk from the city centre this city hall dedicated to a mighty Houston rings to the bygone days and the foundation of what Houston was built on.I quote, 'We fight for the cause of honour,virtue, liberty, pledged to the glory of a mighty Houston' Full of Houston history and contains a visitors shop which has products not obtainable elsewhere. Well worth a visit.

data.title: Historical Building
data.text: Nothing special in the building, a gift shop inside and a detailed metro guide with interactive screen.

data.title: Houston City Hall
data.text: The building is very large and quite impressive.  It is a good builiding to photograph to remember your vacation to the largest city in Tejas.

data.title: 1930s era exterior, murals and interiors--worth visiting
data.text: This 1939 building is full of artistic and architectural items that depict classical, Texan and southern motifs. For example, above the lobby entrance is a stone sculpture depicting two men taming a wild horse. This represents men uniting in government to control the chaotic forces of nature. The plaster cast for this sculpture, and many other friezes around the building, were done by Beaumont artist Herring Coe and co-designer Raoul Jossett who designed several other Texas sculptural landmarks.

data.title: An average structure
data.text: The building is nothing special but it is the seat of our local government. The reflecting pool area is particially shaded and is often the site of festivals and other events. It's nice that the building is lit each night in an array of changing colors.

data.title: Warm atmosphere for a government building
data.text: For the center of the 4th largest city in the U.S., this place is warm and welcoming, in spite of the need for security!

data.title: sad veiw
data.text: building is very different from what you can see on the pictures presented almost everywhere. But still good to see so you can have your own opinion.

data.title: Does anyone like going to city hall
data.text: Judges, police, rude and snotty clerks. Tickets and bailiffs. Not a great way to spend your evenings. Don't speed and you won't have to go. Plain and simple.

data.title: Art Deco
data.text: If you are into the Art Deco building tours drop by City Hall.  Check out the Carnegie Library across the street and the nearby Esperson and Guld Building to complete the experience.

data.title: First stop in Houston
data.text: They have a great visitors exposure to Houston.  Well worth the time.  They have some great souvenirs and a neat video of Houston.

data.title: I wouldn't go out of my way
data.text: I am a 6th generation native Houstonian and I am very proud of my city. Our city hall is a great example of art deco architecture.  However, I wouldn't go out of my way to see it.

data.title: On the weekend the city is QUIET
data.text: Every morning I awoke and after a work out an coffee I would walk around the city.  Yes, there homeless but like every city there is beauty.  Check the photos.

data.title: 909 Bagby Street, Houston Visitors Center.  See it first in Houston
data.text: Great visitors center.  I highly recommend that any visit to Houston starts here in the 1940's style Houston City Hall, from the entry lobby and intricate detail of the inlaid city seals to the vast area of good area information in the visitor's center.
